Dear Ms. Brewer:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
A six-month provisional license is recommended. You must contest or agree to the
issuance of a provisional license in writing, on the CWL-4617 within 15 days, with
submission of the corrective action plan. If you do not submit the CWL-4617, it will be
treated as contested. Even if you contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must
still submit an acceptable corrective action plan.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Tyler Armstrong, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4108 Financing and audit
(1) A licensee shall do all of the following:
(a) Obtain an annual audit of all financial accounts.
Audits for nongovernmental institutions shall be
conducted by an independent certified public
accountant who is not administratively related to
the agency.
An independent yearly audit was not completed for the facility.
CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements;
staff qualifications.
(1) Child caring institutions subject to 42 USC 671 shall
not permit a child caring institution staff member to
begin working unless all of the following has been
completed using the forms, and in the manner,
prescribed by the department:

(a) A criminal record check as referenced in R
400.4113(f), including a fingerprint based check
of national crime information databases, unless
an alternative criminal history check has been
approved by the federal government.
One of the four new employee files reviewed did not have complete
documentation of a criminal history check completed prior to the date of hire.
CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements;
staff qualifications
(1) Child caring institutions subject to 42 USC 671 shall

completed using the forms, and in the manner,
prescribed by the department:
(b) A check of Michigan's child abuse and neglect
central registry or Canadian provincial agency as
referenced in R 400.4113(i).
One of the four new employee files reviewed did not have documentation of a
central registry check completed prior to the date of hire.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(g) If the employee has criminal convictions, the
institution shall complete a written evaluation
of the convictions that addresses the nature
of the conviction, the length of time since the
conviction, and the relationship of the
conviction to regulated activity for the
purpose of determining suitability for
employment in the institution.
One out of the four new employee files reviewed did not have complete

CCI Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and
volunteers
(1) The licensee shall document, prior to employment,

prior to the expiration of the current verification.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• It is inaccurate to provide information to possible community partners that the
facility can provide a service that is not set up for yet and not approved by
DCWL, so that practice should be discontinued.
• If the facility has reached agreement in writing with any other community
partner at any point in time to provide any other service outside what had been
previously approved, then it would be required that an updated Program
Statement and any applicable policies & procedures be provided to DCWL for
review for approval.
• Tracking and ensuring that timely renewals of any CPR and First Aid training is
necessary.

V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility was provided consultation regarding the clear explanation and
organization of documentation within employee files when the employee has
multiple last names in order to ensure clarity.
• The facility was provided consultation regarding the organization and
communication about personnel files and where items are located that are
needed for review.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 11 acceptable corrective action plans (CAPs) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
first was a result of non-compliance at the time of renewal after the first six month
provisional license after the issuance of the original license. This CAP contained
21 rule violations and resulted in 13 action steps. Full compliance was not
achieved as there are repeated rule violations in this inspection. Compliance was
achieved in areas of documentation within youth files. In addition, there were ten
special investigations that had violations causing the need for CAPs, listed below:
• SIR # 2024C0001049SI produced violations related to CCI Rule 400.4142
(1) (e) and 400.4104 (2). The resulting action items related to updating
policy & procedure to ensure the health needs of children at the facility
were met, as well as providing updated policies & procedures to Licensing
for review.
• SIR # 2024C0000927SI produced violations related to CCI Rule 400.4158
(1) (a) (ii). The resulting action items included updates to policy &
procedure to further clarify the non-use of physical management by staff at
the facility.
• SIR # 2024C0000953SI produced a violation related to CCI Rule 400.4126
(1). The resulting action items included updated policies and procedures
regarding supervision of youth.
• SIR # 2024SIC0001223 produced a violation related to CCI Rule 400.4124
(1). The resulting action items included updated policies and procedures
regarding appropriate and allowable communication between youth and
family members, caseworkers, and mental health providers.

• SIR # 2024C0001037SI produced violations related to CCI Rule 400.4158
(1) (a) (ii), 400.4127 (4), 400.4109 (1) (c), 400.4158 (1) (a) (iv), and
400.4116 (1). This special investigation resulted in the issuance of a first
provisional license. The resulting action items included updates to policies
& procedures regarding physical contact between staff and youth, safety
checks of youth during sleeping hours and the supervision of the Chief
Administrator role, as well as further training for staff regarding de-
escalation techniques, verbal abuse of youth, and safe driving standards.
• SIR # 2024SIC0001210 produced a violation related to CCI Rule 400.4142
(1) (d). The resulting action item included changes in policy and
procedures for the storage and access of medications.
• SIR # 2024C0001159SI produced a violation related to CCI Rule 400.4126
(1). The resulting action items included changes to facility practices of the
supervision of youth.
• SIR # 2024SIC0001172 produced a violation related to CCI Rule 400.4142
(1) (a). The resulting action items included changes to policy & procedure
regarding the provision of information on youth placed to medical
providers.
• SIR # 2024C0001091SI produced a violation related to Act 116 Rule
722.120 and CCI Rule 400.4130 (1). The resulting action items included
training for staff on how to speak with youth who are a part of any
investigations as well as updates to policy & procedure regarding the
recording of youth and the facility’s security camera system.
• SIR # 2024SIC0001241 produced a violation related to CCI Rule 400.4130
(1). The resulting action items included updates to policy & procedures
regarding the necessary confidentiality of youth.
Much of the compliance for these CAPs could not be achieved because the
facility had its contract ended for its sole referral source in June of 2024, ending
any further placements since that time. The facility is expected to meet CAP
action items upon new placements with the new approved referral source.
Compliance was achieved in areas of updating policies and procedures to ensure
compliance with licensing rules, further de-escalation and behavior management
training and scheduling of staff to maintain ratio requirements.
Financial Overview
The facility did not provide an independent financial audit for the year, resulting in
a rule violation. Budgeting information was provided. Clarification was needed as
the initial information provided allocated for the next calendar year to include
income from MDHHS placements, which is not currently contracted. Budgeting
also showed planned income from the currently approved referral source to be
higher than previously documented.

PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator provided an assessment dated 12/02/2024. This
assessment expressed barriers to rule compliance as staff turnover, a lack of
support from Licensing, challenges in managing the behavior issues of placed
youth and ineffective leadership at the time of original licensure. The Chief
Administrator assessed the facility is in compliance with Licensing rules and
previous deficiencies have been resolved.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff were interviewed over the phone during this inspection. They expressed
excitement about the new referral source and the program having possible
placements in the near future and discussed recent staff meetings and trainings in
advance of this new programming.
No youth were interviewed for this inspection because the facility has not had any
new placements.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The facility was toured on 12/12/2024 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit.
No concerns were noted. Despite not having recent placements the property was
clean and well maintained, as well as properly stocked with food, cleaning
supplies and other items for possible future placements.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all pplicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency license be modified to a Second Provisional license.
